title: Dawn treader dream
excerpt: I had a really vivid dream last night involving my late friend Corby. Since he passed away in 2018, he‚Äôs shown up in my dreams a few times, but as far as I remember he was alive in those dreams. In this dream he was a ghost, and he knew it and I knew it.

title: Instead of instagram
excerpt: This is a post following up a story I posted on Instagram volunteering to help anyone interested to get off Instagram and onto something more open, with the hopes we could get a little crew together to seed a small network that could be fun enough to keep using. Because of a) everything and b) Meta‚Äôs recent rollback of moderation and/or attempt to cut its workforce in the shittiest way possible, it seems like this is another moment where people are looking around for options. A few people I know are planning to leave the platform right now, so I want this to serve as a reference for them and anyone else interested the next time ripples of dissatsifaction spread across the platform.

title: Lucy's eggs
excerpt: [[Lucy]] wrote about a Real Mind Thing of hers, The Eggs, for a very cool project called the Personal Canons Cookbook.

title: Patterns of intention
excerpt: Walking up to [[Martha]]‚Äôs recent art show at [[Mother Foucault‚Äôs]], I saw Patterns of Intention in the window. They‚Äôre distressingly good at putting books I want in the window ‚Äì I think 90% of the books I‚Äôve bought there have come from the window. Or maybe I‚Äôm just a lazy browser and need to literally see it from the street to pay attention.

backlink_index.title: I Can't Stop Galaxy Braining
backlink_index.excerpt: I have very strong, interconnected synesthesia. This makes categorization of really any kind rather non-linear for me. I‚Äôm glad to have avoided developing a need for things to be categorized accurately and completely, because nothing ever is, but I‚Äôm always looking for a bit more room in definitions, and noting which things overlap with which and where the mental threads connect. And sometimes (most times) one thing is like another thing, but only in a certain way. How are you supposed to put everything into rows and columns? Tags are such a good solution to this. You can add one, or a thousand, and you don‚Äôt even need to know what else they apply to yet. They‚Äôre a facet of something. Everything is always facets. This is the road to galaxy braining, and it starts from anywhere and everywhere.

backlink_index.title: Amy bay at nationale

title: The Paddleboat Family
excerpt: In the middling time between Portland‚Äôs winter and spring last year, we noticed a small nest in one of the trees in the courtyard of our apartment building. It‚Äôs really more of an outdoor hallway than a courtyard, and the trees are pretty rangy Japanese maples ‚Äì not exactly the great outdoors. It was my second spring in this building in an apartment facing that courtyard, and I‚Äôd seen hummingbirds before ‚Äì even the start of another nest. But never a hummingbird in the nest. Without flowers or even buds on the maples, I didn‚Äôt expect to see much more. But there it was, an espresso-cup sized nest made of lichen, sticks, and fluff.

title: The Bun Family
excerpt: Something incredible has happened in the short two weeks since I posted about the hummingbird family that lives in our courtyard, [[The Paddleboat Family.]]

title: Meet the Bun Boys
excerpt: Hummingbirb update. Ms. Bao Bun had to lil fluffpoops that turned into iridescent hovering zoomers in, like, three weeks.

title: Weird web october favorites
excerpt: I‚Äôm still curating this list but these are some of my favorites from Weird Web October. Go find your own favs here!

title: Guidebook to the viridian maw
excerpt: The first in a series of self-published zines meant to stoke the imaginations of tabletop role players, Forking Paths #1: Guidebook to the Viridian Maw has given me and my friends literally hundreds of hours of engaged, high-fantasy imagination time. Each issue in the series describes an original imaginary land with detailed descriptions of its history, features, and creatures, but loosely enough that it can be used to play in any system you want, or just read for enjoyment. The Viridian Maw itself is ‚Äúan overgrown meteor crater, mutated and reshaped by fungal influence,‚Äù and the illustrations are great. A treasured object.

title: The burglar's guide to the city
slug: The Burglar's Guide to The City
excerpt: Because of Octothorpes, I saw that [[Nik]] posted about Design and Crime, so I‚Äôd like to post about The Burglar‚Äôs Guide to The City, another great book about architecture and crime that my friend Stephanie turned me on to. Just finished it, very good. Hope you see this, Nik!

title: The Conceptual Labor Book
excerpt: This is the Conceptual Labor book that I wrote.

backlink_index.title: Mind Things
backlink_index.excerpt: A Mind Thing is something you reach for in your mind as part of how you understand the world. If it‚Äôs all just a pile of Lego up there, (or [[urs]]) then Mind Things are pre-assembled chunks, whether they were deliberately created over painstaking study or just sort of glommed together coincidentally in the eddies of regular mental currents.

backlink_index.title: Nik Wise
backlink_index.excerpt: Nik made a garden at the same time I started getting into this.

title: Ada's three kinds of things
excerpt: Children of her¬†type contrive the purest philosophies. Ada had worked out her own¬†little system. Hardly a week had elapsed since Van‚Äôs arrival when¬†he was found worthy of being initiated in her web of wisdom. An¬†individual‚Äôs life consisted of certain classified things: ‚Äúreal¬†things‚Äù which were unfrequent and priceless, simply ‚Äúthings‚Äù¬†which formed the routine stuff of life; and ‚Äúghost things,‚Äù¬†also called ‚Äúfogs,‚Äù such as fever, toothache, dreadful¬†disappointments, and death. Three or more things occurring at the¬†same time formed a ‚Äútower,‚Äù or, if they came in immediate¬†succession, they made a ‚Äúbridge.‚Äù ‚ÄúReal towers‚Äù¬†and ‚Äúreal bridges‚Äù were the joys of life, and when the¬†towers came in a series, one experienced supreme rapture; it almost¬†never happened, though. In some circumstances, in a certain light, a¬†neutral ‚Äúthing‚Äù might look or even actually become ‚Äúreal‚Äù¬†or else, conversely, it might coagulate into a fetid ‚Äúfog.‚Äù

title: Lossy compiler
excerpt: This is a retronym made necessary by the growing expectation that information and culture can be perfect transmitted ‚Äì that the result on one end will be identical to the thing transmitted. Humans are lossy compilers, and cultural output made for humans should expect that it will be received in a way that deviate from the original product.

title: Bread times
excerpt: Discussing Bread Times is how [[Martha]] and I acknowledged the existence and importance of times. I think this was before we lived together, and one of us was harshly shaming the other after discovering a bag of dinner rolls in his kitchen that he had purchased for his own consumption.

title: Slow motion bullseyes
excerpt: The first bookstore I worked at was [[Dawn Treader Books]], a classic, all-topics used bookstore (with a particularly strong showing in fiction, especially science fiction). I was 17, and I had also recently started volunteering at WCBN, the community radio station.

title: Stone souping
excerpt: When multiple people are interested in a project or an idea or an activity, and no one has a plan or has actually taken action, but in talking to each other they end up with a plan accidentally. The most common way for this to work is to assume the other person has it more together than you do and lean on their imagined plan to consolidate yours.

title: The mole diagram
excerpt: Back in art school, I had a dream where I was trying to explain to my friend Greg a tension I was feeling with my studies. I went to art school to focus on being a painter, but once I got there I also joined a martial arts school, started my if-you‚Äôre-going-to-get-a-degree-in-painting-you-have-to-learn-how-to-code bargain with myself, and was still writing all the time. I was supposed to be painting, but The Thing I was Trying to Do seemed to pop up in all those realms.

title: Wushi
excerpt: Lacking by the elegance and refinement of sushi, free of the ‚Äúgood recipes‚Äù of tapas, and void of the cachet of nouvelle-cuisine, Wushi is distinguished from other small-plate traditions by placing priority on the question ‚Äúwhat do I want to put in my mouth‚Äù rather than the question ‚Äúwhat should I put in my mouth‚Äù.

title: A group is its own worst enemy
slug: A Group is its Own Worst Enemy
excerpt: While that definition‚Äîsoftware for group interaction‚Äîcuts across existing categories, I think it is the right one, because it recognizes the fundamentally social nature of the problem. Groups are a runtime effect.You cannot specify in advance what any given group will do, and so you can‚Äôt instantiate in software everything you expect to have happen. Now, there‚Äôs a large body of literature saying, ‚ÄúWe built this soft-ware, a group came and used it, and they began to exhibit behaviors that surprised us enormously, so we‚Äôve gone and documented these behaviors.‚Äù Over and over and over again this pattern comes up.

title: What is a memex
excerpt:
‚ÄúMemex‚Äù is a portmanteau of ‚Äúmemory‚Äù and ‚Äúindex,‚Äù coined by Vannevar Bush in his essay As We May Think. It was an idea far ahead of its time for a system ‚Äúthat would permit a researcher to follow and annotate topics of interest, analogous to later hypertext technologies.‚Äù It sounds like a personal database, but it was supposed to be more than that ‚Äì an extension of an individual‚Äôs memory and curiosity that was designed not just to store information, but to help them recall and link things they stored in a meaningful way.

It‚Äôs an early vision of how information technology could expand the human memory and serve its curiosity and inquiry.

image: /assets/buckmanite/Buckmanite - Typical Substrate Total Formation Wide View.jpeg
title: Buckmanite
excerpt: Buckmanite, or Buckman Slate, is a metamorphic substance endemic to many urban environments, but first identified in the Buckman neighborhood of Portland, Oregon. It is a composite material formed when plastic municipal containers undergo rapid exothermic reactions, deforming to bond with the surrounding environment. These reactions are most often triggered by human intervention, both accidental and intentional, but theoretically could be triggered by natural phenomena such as lightning or incidental lensing of sunlight through nearby mirrors or windows during a heatwave.

title: Dorians
excerpt: In January of 2024 I had a dream in which my dear friend Gina was known to always be carrying, and snacking from, a basket of Dorians. Dorians, as everyone in the world of the dream already knew, were a beloved European cookie, as reknowned and revered as the Madelines and Financiers of our world.

title: Magic masala chips
excerpt: My dear and amazing friend [[Vee]] sent me a wadded-up, 1/3-full bag of Magic Masala flavor Lays. We have an ongoing chip and snack discourse. I once sent them a single chip and single animal cracker in a custom made cardboard sleeve. They also were responsible for the Chip Bar at my wedding. Apparently the experience of eating these chips was too intense to keep to themselves, and before the bag was finished they crammed them into an envelope and sent them to me. I treasure my friends. What follows is the review I sent by text upon receiving the package:

title: The old seal
excerpt: Last time Martha and I visited our dear friends Phil and Ellen and got to see Phil‚Äôs amazing collection of books, an unusual item stuck out. It was a very intact royal order and wax seal from 1275. As in the thirteenth century. It‚Äôs ‚Äúnot very interesting‚Äù to collectors because it comes from Phillip II, Duke of Savor, who was only duke for about a year.

I have a feeling that it was designed as smoker‚Äôs furniture, but it‚Äôs pretty good writer‚Äôs furniture. Fits notebooks and one pencil quite well. I added the felt top, which is regular walnut on the reverse.

backlink_index.title: Dorians
backlink_index.excerpt: In January of 2024 I had a dream in which my dear friend Gina was known to always be carrying, and snacking from, a basket of Dorians. Dorians, as everyone in the world of the dream already knew, were a beloved European cookie, as reknowned and revered as the Madelines and Financiers of our world.

backlink_index.title: Amy bay at nationale
Tusker Bottlecap With Andes Mint Wrapper
backlink_index.excerpt: This is the object that made me resolve to document everything in [[Martha]]‚Äôs bag. It had been a long, long journey to get to our wedding, spanning multiple road trips and the first two years of the pandemic. It was very late on the night of our wedding, and we were having an emotional connection with our friend Drew, who had d.j.‚Äôd for us. I dug around in Martha‚Äôs bag to give him more money, and found this bottle cap. It was from the trip to Africa Martha took right after we first met, one of two she‚Äôd take that year, which made her seem very worldly and well-traveled to me. The Andes mint wrapper crammed in the back was unmistakably from the bottomless bowl of free Andes mints at the Roadside Attraction bar in our old neighborhood in Portland, which we hadn‚Äôt been to for years because of the Pandemic and moving way. Indellible artifacts from two different, distinct parts of our lives, both seemingly a million years gone, plinking to the floor in a moment that very concretely felt like the point on which our lives were pivoting to become something new.

backlink_index.title: Adventures of A & N
backlink_index.excerpt: Good friends go on good road trips with you. Even better friends make a free-associative book of snippets of what you saw and talked about on that roadtrip.

title: Dawn treader books
excerpt: Dawn Treader is a bookstore in Ann Arbor, founded in 1976. [[Corby]] ran it for years and always let me work there when I ended up back in Ann Arbor for some dumb reason or another as a 20-something. After he passed away, Africa Schuamann, who had been manager for a while, really took over and eventually bought the place. She‚Äôs really done right by the place, including replacing the awful florescent lights with classy pendant lights. She was also the one who let us in to the basement to rescue Corby‚Äôs years of rude collages.

backlink_index.title: Dawn treader dream
backlink_index.excerpt: I had a really vivid dream last night involving my late friend Corby. Since he passed away in 2018, he‚Äôs shown up in my dreams a few times, but as far as I remember he was alive in those dreams. In this dream he was a ghost, and he knew it and I knew it.

backlink_index.title: Slow motion bullseyes
backlink_index.excerpt: The first bookstore I worked at was [[Dawn Treader Books]], a classic, all-topics used bookstore (with a particularly strong showing in fiction, especially science fiction). I was 17, and I had also recently started volunteering at WCBN, the community radio station.

title: Mother foucault's
excerpt: Mother Foucault‚Äôs is a bookstore in the dirty southeast of Portland Oregon run by Craig. Here‚Äôs a picture of him at work:

backlink_index.title: Patterns of intention
backlink_index.excerpt: Walking up to [[Martha]]‚Äôs recent art show at [[Mother Foucault‚Äôs]], I saw Patterns of Intention in the window. They‚Äôre distressingly good at putting books I want in the window ‚Äì I think 90% of the books I‚Äôve bought there have come from the window. Or maybe I‚Äôm just a lazy browser and need to literally see it from the street to pay attention.

backlink_index.title: I Can't Stop Galaxy Braining
backlink_index.excerpt: I have very strong, interconnected synesthesia. This makes categorization of really any kind rather non-linear for me. I‚Äôm glad to have avoided developing a need for things to be categorized accurately and completely, because nothing ever is, but I‚Äôm always looking for a bit more room in definitions, and noting which things overlap with which and where the mental threads connect. And sometimes (most times) one thing is like another thing, but only in a certain way. How are you supposed to put everything into rows and columns? Tags are such a good solution to this. You can add one, or a thousand, and you don‚Äôt even need to know what else they apply to yet. They‚Äôre a facet of something. Everything is always facets. This is the road to galaxy braining, and it starts from anywhere and everywhere.

title: Worker's tap
excerpt: The Worker‚Äôs Tap is basically our extra living room. It‚Äôs a worker-owned anarchist socialist lefty everything bar run by and frequented by the nicest people. We‚Äôve played DnD there about a million times. They let me have my birthday there, and when [[Mykle]] and [[Jon]] and I got stuck in the middle of the World Naked Bike Ride by Michael‚Äôs Italian Beef*, they let me come in and order a beer as long as I had ‚Äúsomething covering my lower half.‚Äù

title: The Record Tree

title: Research club
excerpt: From 2009 to 2015, Research Club was a collectively-run organization that hosted a free, monthly brunch where local artists, makers, and organizers gave semi-formal talks about the projects that they were working on, the problems they were trying to solve, and the people that they were inspired by.

title: Octotest
excerpt: This page is using the Octothorpe Protocol

title: Sparql functions
excerpt:
1. String Functions

  • STR(?var): Converts an IRI or literal to a string.
  • STRLEN(?str): Returns the length of a string.
  • CONTAINS(?str, ‚Äúsubstring‚Äù): Checks if a string contains a substring.
  • STRSTARTS(?str, ‚Äúprefix‚Äù): Checks if a string starts with a prefix.
  • STRENDS(?str, ‚Äúsuffix‚Äù): Checks if a string ends with a suffix.
  • SUBSTR(?str, start, length): Extracts a substring from a string.
  • UCASE(?str): Converts a string to uppercase.
  • LCASE(?str): Converts a string to lowercase.
  • REPLACE(?str, ‚Äúpattern‚Äù, ‚Äúreplacement‚Äù): Replaces parts of a string.

title: Time confetti and the broken promise of leisure
slug: Time Confetti and The Broken Promise of Leisure
excerpt: Technology saves us time, but it also takes it away. This is known as the autonomy paradox. We adopt mobile technologies to gain autonomy over when and how long we work, yet, ironically, we end up working all the time. Long blocks of free time we used to enjoy are now interrupted constantly by our smart watches, phones, tablets, and laptops.

title: After xoxo
excerpt: There was a particularly strong thread that ran through most of my conversations at XOXO this year. It was braided from questions (pleas?) like the following:

title: Handmade images print version
excerpt: What does it mean for an image to be made by hand? In general usage, calling something handmade places a certain amount of care and responsibility with the maker. If you made a pie by hand you can take credit for its deliciousness. You wave off compliments if it‚Äôs store-bought. But just as handmade pies lean on the qualities of their ingredients, even the most handmade of images are inseparable from the physical, non-human properties of the tools and materials that someone‚Äôs hands used in the making. How much we let those properties matter in our reading of an image depends on where we locate the ‚Äúart‚Äù of the process; i.e. where we expect the presence of an artist doing art in a way that matters to the image.

title: I Can't Stop Galaxy Braining
excerpt: I have very strong, interconnected synesthesia. This makes categorization of really any kind rather non-linear for me. I‚Äôm glad to have avoided developing a need for things to be categorized accurately and completely, because nothing ever is, but I‚Äôm always looking for a bit more room in definitions, and noting which things overlap with which and where the mental threads connect. And sometimes (most times) one thing is like another thing, but only in a certain way. How are you supposed to put everything into rows and columns? Tags are such a good solution to this. You can add one, or a thousand, and you don‚Äôt even need to know what else they apply to yet. They‚Äôre a facet of something. Everything is always facets. This is the road to galaxy braining, and it starts from anywhere and everywhere.

title: We really like personal sites but the internet has been turning into poisonous garbage at an alarming rate
slug: We Really Like Personal Sites But the Internet Has Been Turning into Poisonous Garbage At An Alarming Rate
excerpt: Part of me wants to talk about how fun the internet was when it was just websites. But we barely had tags then, let alone hashtags. Much like the ‚ÄúY2K Garage Sale‚Äù that happened down the street from me, any nostalgia I have for that time is selective memory indelibly colored by all the work that we did to improve things since the early 2000s. I remember enjoying reading the internet much more back then, but writing it felt much worse.

title: Interdependence Day
excerpt: üéâ Interdependence Day üéâ is my made-up holiday in which I make a gift to send to all of my friends, as a way of saying hi at least once a year ‚Äì a semi-meditative, semi-stressful practice to spend hours remembering the people I care about. I‚Äôve been doing it since the early 2000s, making a range of choices about what constitutes a ‚Äúgift‚Äù or what people ‚Äúwant.‚Äù I‚Äôve mostly settled on making papercuts inspired by the Polish art of Wycinanki, but you‚Äôll find a few other inventions here as well.

backlink_index.title: Wushi
backlink_index.excerpt: Lacking by the elegance and refinement of sushi, free of the ‚Äúgood recipes‚Äù of tapas, and void of the cachet of nouvelle-cuisine, Wushi is distinguished from other small-plate traditions by placing priority on the question ‚Äúwhat do I want to put in my mouth‚Äù rather than the question ‚Äúwhat should I put in my mouth‚Äù.

author: Nim
definition: A cooler way to say 'the Information Superhighway'
title: Infobahn
excerpt: You can only get [[internet+]] on the Infobahn.

definition: The basic, underlying format of how you conceive of anything. The language your brain uses. The quanta of thought.
author: Nim
title: Urs

backlink_index.title: Mind Things
backlink_index.excerpt: A Mind Thing is something you reach for in your mind as part of how you understand the world. If it‚Äôs all just a pile of Lego up there, (or [[urs]]) then Mind Things are pre-assembled chunks, whether they were deliberately created over painstaking study or just sort of glommed together coincidentally in the eddies of regular mental currents.

backlink_index.title: Yunnan Red Honey Process

author: Jon
definition: an association that either makes sense at first but not after thinking about it, or one that doesn't make sense at first but kinda feels right after you sit with it.
title: Hypolink
excerpt: Once in the early days of the Infobahn, [[Jon]] and I were in a conversation where somone waxed poetic about how hyperlinks are like how the mind works, connecting concepts and terms, and Jon uttered the ‚ÄúJon noise‚Äù ‚Äì a sort of warble of equal parts elation and confusion and acceptence ‚Äì and said ‚ÄúI feel like my brain is mainly hyPOlinks‚Äù

author: Nim
definition: Pronounced "pee dee", this refers to a state of extreme cuteness and patheticness, like a kitten wrapped up in a towel, or when you are sick and you want to sink into the couch cushions with a cookie balanced on your chest.
title: Pede
excerpt: This came to me in a dream about cats. The cats in the dream were being very, very pede. I loved that dream.

author: Jon
definition: Undefinable. Pruntiness can only be demonstrated, as it is a particular way of being. It combines aspects of sassiness, pride, feeling-one's-self, smallness and/or roundness, ungovernableness, and mischief.
title: Prunty
excerpt: To see a creature be truly prunty, watch a cat steal food without consequence and trot away from the scene of their crime with the food in their mouth, knowing no one can catch them.

author: Jon
definition: Acronym meaning There Is No Such Thing as Coincidence
title: Tinstac
excerpt: T.I.N.S.T.A.C. stands for There Is No Such Thing as Coincidence, coined by [[Jon]], because life, well, it be that way.

excerpt: This is a plug of fancy pink salt, probably from the Johnson‚Äôs Salt distro nearby. I assume it was placed here by human hands, and not extruded from the building.

title: rikimbili.jpeg
excerpt:
1. Repurposed plastic crate used for food and supply delivery
  2. Gravity fed gas tank, mounted with a strap tied through the crate
  3. Handle for engaging the direct-drive transmission, which consists of pressing the motor‚Äôs driveshaft to the back wheel.
  4. Handmade second seat, likely out of palm wood. These seats are very common on all types of bicycles in Cuba. Note the foot pegs to accommodate children.
  5. Modern, ergonomic handlebars.
  6. The entire rear section had been rebuilt to make it possible to replace the back wheel with a motorcycle wheel.
  7. Handmade kickstand, welded and bolted from scrap metal.
  8. Brand new Chinese made LED headlamp
  9. Handmade shock absorbers.

title: Los Tonos
excerpt: Aka The Heart of Jesus or the Two Week Old Pineapple. Was described as having an undertone like the taste pineapple gets when you leave it out on the counter for a couple weeks. Accurate, and delicious.

title: Buckmanite Samples
excerpt: [[Buckmanite]], or Buckman Slate, is a metamorphic substance endemic to many urban environments, but first identified in the Buckman neighborhood of Portland, Oregon. It is a composite material formed when plastic municipal containers undergo rapid exothermic reactions, deforming to bond with the surrounding environment.

backlink_index.title: Buckmanite
backlink_index.excerpt: Buckmanite, or Buckman Slate, is a metamorphic substance endemic to many urban environments, but first identified in the Buckman neighborhood of Portland, Oregon. It is a composite material formed when plastic municipal containers undergo rapid exothermic reactions, deforming to bond with the surrounding environment. These reactions are most often triggered by human intervention, both accidental and intentional, but theoretically could be triggered by natural phenomena such as lightning or incidental lensing of sunlight through nearby mirrors or windows during a heatwave.

title: Everything in My Wife's Bag Two Days After We Got Married
slug: Everything in My Wife's Bag Two Days After We Got Married
excerpt: The [[Tusker Bottlecap With Andes Mint Wrapper]] is the object that made me resolve to document everything in [[Martha]]‚Äôs bag. It had been a long, long journey to get to our wedding, spanning multiple road trips and the first two years of the pandemic. It was very late on the night of our wedding, and we were having an emotional connection with our friend Drew, who had d.j.‚Äôd for us. I dug around in Martha‚Äôs bag to give him more money, and found this bottle cap. It was from the trip to Africa Martha took right after we first met, one of two she‚Äôd take that year, which made her seem very worldly and well-traveled to me. The Andes mint wrapper crammed in the back was unmistakably from the bottomless bowl of free Andes mints at the Roadside Attraction bar in our old neighborhood in Portland, which we hadn‚Äôt been to for years because of the Pandemic and moving way. Indellible artifacts from two different, distinct parts of our lives, both seemingly a million years gone, plinking to the floor in a moment that very concretely felt like the point on which our lives were pivoting to become something new.

title: Pika's Place
excerpt: Someone has been leaving touching memorials for their son, who went by Pika, on the same pillar of the Morrison Bridge since at least 2019. This was right outside the door to my studio for years, so I did my best to document it whenever I could before the Portland graffiti removal team would paint over it. Pika, I didn‚Äôt know you, but you are remembered.üñ§üñ§üñ§

backlink_index.title: Mind Things
backlink_index.excerpt: A Mind Thing is something you reach for in your mind as part of how you understand the world. If it‚Äôs all just a pile of Lego up there, (or [[urs]]) then Mind Things are pre-assembled chunks, whether they were deliberately created over painstaking study or just sort of glommed together coincidentally in the eddies of regular mental currents.

backlink_index.title: I Can't Stop Galaxy Braining
backlink_index.excerpt: I have very strong, interconnected synesthesia. This makes categorization of really any kind rather non-linear for me. I‚Äôm glad to have avoided developing a need for things to be categorized accurately and completely, because nothing ever is, but I‚Äôm always looking for a bit more room in definitions, and noting which things overlap with which and where the mental threads connect. And sometimes (most times) one thing is like another thing, but only in a certain way. How are you supposed to put everything into rows and columns? Tags are such a good solution to this. You can add one, or a thousand, and you don‚Äôt even need to know what else they apply to yet. They‚Äôre a facet of something. Everything is always facets. This is the road to galaxy braining, and it starts from anywhere and everywhere.

title: words
excerpt: There are a lot of words out there that are pretty easy to find. So I‚Äôve focused on harder to find words, ones that I or friends have discovered on our own. If you have discovered any words, please do submit them for inclusion.
